bibl.title: Letter from J. Martinez H. to Laura Armistead Carter, February 14, 1932

div1.p: Martinez thanks Miss Carter for the copy of her father's book and discusses theories of disease in Mayan Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from J. Martinez H. to Laura Armistead Carter, February 14, 1932
div1.p:
J. Martínez H.,
calle 25 núm. 500,
Mérida, Yucatan,
Mexico.
Feb. 14th., 1932. Miss Laura Armstead Carter,
Richmond Apts.,
2030 Highland Ave.
Birmingham,
Alabama,
U.S.A.
My dear Miss Carter:-

I had the pleasure to receive the book you
kindly sent me entitled “Yellow Fever”, the postumous work of
your worthy father for which I thank you.

I feel that it is a very great honor for me to have
my name in its pages. The book was lent to the different members
of the staff of the Carnegie Institution doing work at Chic-en
Itzá, Dr. Kidder, Dr. Merriam and Dr. Morley, the last mentioned in
your book. The consensus of opinion is that the book is a scho-
larly work. I can appreciate its importance by the way the sub-
ject is handled and examined under all posible conditions, so
that his conclusions carry conviction to the mind. You should be
proud in having such a father.

Under separte cover I am to day mailing you my “Ma-
yan Lunar Table, read before the XXIII International Congress
of Americanists”, in New York, in 1928. According to my correla-
tion the 4 Ahau is either 1224-1244, or 1480-1500. Dr. Morley's
places this date about 257 years before, hence your father
could not explain how smallpox could have been mentioned in
the years 1477-1500. this deasease was brouth over in 1920 by
the expedition of Pánfilo de Narvaez. A sick negro brought it
on board and spread it in Cozumel island. This single case
proves the innacuracy of Dr. Morley's correlation. It is mentio-
ned in the Books of Chilam Balam, on 2 Ahau. the one following 4 Ahau,
and includes from 1500 to 1520. Morley would place it in katun
2 Ahau, between 1497 and 1517, at a time when no expedition had
landed in Mexico. 11 Ahau, is from 1539 to 1559. So you see how
the evidence brought by your father is in favor of my correla-
tion which, of late has been accepted by scientists. (p.122 of
“Yellow fever”. Can Ahau, the pestilence is between 1480-1500.
Mayacimlal, according to Die. Docul, 1577, is una mortandad grande
que uvo en Yucatan y tómase por qualquier mortandad o pesti-
lencia que lleva mucha gente/.p.287) The author, Fray Antonio de
Ciudad Real died in Yucatan in 1617 having spent 40 years of
his life in Yucatan. The mayacimil took place before the coming
of the Spaniards in 1542.
Hoping this finds you enjoying health, I remain,

Yours sincerely,
J Martinez H
(Over)

C1
B20

8 Ahau, time elapsed from 1441 to 1460. During this time the Ma
Mayapan confederacy was broken.
6 Ahau: time elapsed from 1460 to 1480. No record.

4 Ahau: time elapsed from 1480 to 1500. uchci mayacimlal, uchci
ocna-kuchil ich paa. The pestlence that carried many people
2 Ahau: time elapsed uchci kakil nohkakil. Smallpox. 1500 to 1520.

13 Ahau: time elapsed from 1520 to 1539. Death of the scrifice
offerers, which took place. elsewhere in 1535. The Spa-
nish year calendar was introduced.

11 Ahau; time elapsed from 1539 to 1559. They brought desease
to us in Yucatan, fro the first tieme

9 Ahau: from 1559 to 1579. Arrival of
Bishop Toral. Preaching of Cristianism began here.
7 Ahau: from 1579 to 1638. Death of Bishop Landa.

Extracts from my booklet “Cronicas Mayas” pp. 26-27. Book
First of Cumayel

4 Ahau: previous, 1224 to 1244. Took posetion of Mayapan, and the
probable arrival with them of Kukulcan. No smallpox
or pestilence mentioned.

This agrees with the intelligent criticism of Dr. Carter
in his book “Yellow Fever”. There is no record of such
deseas in the Maya Chronicles. It is to be found only in the
ritualistic prophcies given by the High Priest at the
expiration of each katun, a sort of historical forecast
of probable events and calamities. The Mayas were a pesimiscti
people. There are more unlucky days in their yearly calendar
than lucky ones.
J.M.H. Feb. 14 of 1932.
